dcc7ed6948f1.name: Felicia C. Sullivan

paragraphs.name: 32bf
paragraphs.text: I was such an asshole to Rachel, smiling to her face while gossiping behind her back. I cringe when I think about it now, embarrassed by the kind of person I used to be. Even though our friendship didn’t last long I still think about how mean I was to her, even now, nearly two decades later, because I made her feel the way I had felt in high school, tormented for no reason other than the fact that I existed. It’s easy to spread one’s pain like sickness instead of tending to our wounds.

paragraphs.name: b52e
paragraphs.text: Hate is ultimately self-destructive. The ill we wish toward others becomes our conception of how others regard ourselves. This holds true for every sin. The theif worries that someone will take his stuff; the liar cannot trust other people, much less himself. The cheater in marriage is filled with jealousy. We exempt ourselves from the rules that…

paragraphs.name: 31b4
paragraphs.text: I’m guilty of online arguing and hate myself. I’ve also bore the brunt of it like most others that spending any time at all in online forums or social media. I enjoy the internet an today’s tech that makes it possible, but sometimes I long for the mid-90s or even early 2000s before it became so easy and pervasive. To be honest, I think I was a much…

When I watch people dragged off a plane, or make a conscience decision not to take my children to live sporting events, or cringe as I listen to a cab blow his horn at someone crossing the…

10314375eb2c.title: Choosing to be cruel is directly related to insecurities, as you illustrate with your honest essay.

paragraphs.name: 3ed2
paragraphs.text: Choosing to be cruel is directly related to insecurities, as you illustrate with your honest essay. I wonder if it’s always been this way but we just didn’t see it as clearly (because the Internet really is the perfect platform for bullying) or have we as people grown meaner and unhappier? Both? One fueling the other I suppose.

paragraphs.text: Hal,

I think decorum is definitely part of it, but I’ll stretch that and say many are losing basic compassion and empathy for others. Someone else commented on the notion of caring vs. empathy and how we journey from a place of decency and compassion to empathy, and finally to caring. It’s hard to come from a place of hate…

paragraphs.name: 7e59
paragraphs.text: I think a lot of it comes from fear, or at least that’s where mine came from. Fear that I’ll never be accepted for who I am rather than what I project, fear of failure in publishing, fear that I won’t have the life I want, etc., and I think out of the fear comes envy and resentment, and that could, coupled with insecurity, dovetail to the hate we see…

7f8a39ddce69.title: I once read somewhere, ‘when you’re a writer, those who are the most vocal against you are often…

paragraphs.name: 581f
paragraphs.text: I once read somewhere, ‘when you’re a writer, those who are the most vocal against you are often the ones who admire you the most.’ I don’t know anymore; sure, I’ve been jealous of writers before, but there seems to be a dearth of criticism online, especially in writing groups, designed to kill the messenger. Those who are the loudest are often the ones not saying anything.
